items.title: Swiss bar fire was like 'hell': Survivors recount ski resort blaze
items.standfirst: CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland — Ringing in the new year with a night of drinking and dancing high in the Swiss Alps, Ebenezer Mehari, 17, decided to take a breather outside the packed Constellation Bar

items.title: Swiss bar fire likely started by sparklers on champagne bottles
items.standfirst: The investigation into the fire that killed 40 people will consider whether criminal prosecutions are necessary, officials said.
items.content: The investigation into the fire that killed 40 people will consider whether criminal prosecutions are necessary, officials said.

items.title: Switzerland resort fire ‘likely started by sparklers in champagne bottles’, says attorney general – as it happened
items.standfirst: Officials say 40 people were killed and 119 injured, with some in hospital still unidentified due to ‘horrific’ injuriesItaly’s ambassador to Switzerland Gian Lorenzo Cornado has said that all bar five of the 112 injured have been identified now, reports Reuters. Swiss officials are yet to give an update on this and have not shared the names of any victims or injured.Six Italians are still missing and 13 hospitalised, he added. Three Italians were repatriated on Thursday and three more will follow on Friday, he said.It’s the grief, as if we have all lost a loved one. Continue reading...
items.content: Officials say 40 people were killed and 119 injured, with some in hospital still unidentified due to ‘horrific’ injuriesItaly’s ambassador to Switzerland Gian Lorenzo Cornado has said that all bar five of the 112 injured have been identified now, reports Reuters. Swiss officials are yet to give an update on this and have not shared the names of any victims or injured.Six Italians are still missing and 13 hospitalised, he added. Three Italians were repatriated on Thursday and three more will follow on Friday, he said.It’s the grief, as if we have all lost a loved one. Continue reading...

items.title: Sparklers held near ceiling started Swiss ski resort fire, investigators believe
items.standfirst: Footage and witness statements show blaze that killed about 40 was ‘very rapid’, prosecutor saysInvestigators believe fountain sparklers mounted on champagne bottles and held too close to the ceiling sparked the deadly fire that tore through a crowded bar in the ski resort of Crans-Montana, killing about 40 people and injuring more than 100.“Everything suggests the fire started from the burning candles or ‘Bengal lights’ that had been attached to champagne bottles,” the prosecutor Béatrice Pilloud said on Friday. “These went too close to the ceiling.” Continue reading...
items.content: Footage and witness statements show blaze that killed about 40 was ‘very rapid’, prosecutor saysInvestigators believe fountain sparklers mounted on champagne bottles and held too close to the ceiling sparked the deadly fire that tore through a crowded bar in the ski resort of Crans-Montana, killing about 40 people and injuring more than 100.“Everything suggests the fire started from the burning candles or ‘Bengal lights’ that had been attached to champagne bottles,” the prosecutor Béatrice Pilloud said on Friday. “These went too close to the ceiling.” Continue reading...

items.title: New Year’s Eve sparklers may have caused deadly Swiss bar fire: Official
items.standfirst: Families face agonising wait as investigators work to identify at least 40 people killed, many others wounded in blaze.
items.content: Families face agonising wait as investigators work to identify at least 40 people killed, many others wounded in blaze.

items.title: What happened in the Crans-Montana bar fire in Switzerland – visual guide
items.standfirst: While the cause of the disaster is still under investigation, videos and photos suggest the blaze spread quicklySwitzerland is reeling from one of its worst tragedies after a fire ripped through an Alpine bar during a New Year’s Eve celebration, leaving more than 40 people dead and dozens of others with serious burn injuries.The prosecutor in charge of the case said on Friday that initial investigations suggested the most likely cause of the fire was sparkling flares being carried too close to the ceiling. Continue reading...
items.content: While the cause of the disaster is still under investigation, videos and photos suggest the blaze spread quicklySwitzerland is reeling from one of its worst tragedies after a fire ripped through an Alpine bar during a New Year’s Eve celebration, leaving more than 40 people dead and dozens of others with serious burn injuries.The prosecutor in charge of the case said on Friday that initial investigations suggested the most likely cause of the fire was sparkling flares being carried too close to the ceiling. Continue reading...

items.title: Swiss bar fire started by sparklers, investigators say, amid efforts to ID victims
items.standfirst: Many of those killed and injured by a fire that tore through a bar in Switzerland's Crans-Montana ski resort were teenagers celebrating the new year.
items.content: Many of those killed and injured by a fire that tore through a bar in Switzerland's Crans-Montana ski resort were teenagers celebrating the new year.

items.title: Crans-Montana fire survivors treated in burns units across Europe
items.standfirst: Some of the injured taken to Belgium, France and Germany while Swiss officials try to identify the deadSurvivors of the catastrophic bar fire in the upmarket Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana are being cared for in special burns units across Europe, while investigators say many of the dead were so badly burned that it could take days or weeks to identify them.About 40 people were killed and 119 injured when the blaze ripped through a New Year’s Eve celebration in the packed Le Constellation bar and basement nightclub. Investigators believe sparkling candles or sparklers that were put on bottles of champagne and moved too close to the ceiling started the fire. Continue reading...
items.content: Some of the injured taken to Belgium, France and Germany while Swiss officials try to identify the deadSurvivors of the catastrophic bar fire in the upmarket Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana are being cared for in special burns units across Europe, while investigators say many of the dead were so badly burned that it could take days or weeks to identify them.About 40 people were killed and 119 injured when the blaze ripped through a New Year’s Eve celebration in the packed Le Constellation bar and basement nightclub. Investigators believe sparkling candles or sparklers that were put on bottles of champagne and moved too close to the ceiling started the fire. Continue reading...

items.title: Crans-Montana fire likely caused by sparklers on Champagne bottles
items.standfirst: Initial investigations ​suggest that ⁠the fire which tore through a Swiss ski resort ​bar started ‍when 'fountain candles' attached ​to champagne bottles were carried ​aloft too close to the ceiling, the local prosecutor said on Friday. Authorities planned to look into whether the material on the ceiling that was designed to muffle sound conformed with regulations. FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot is on the ground.
items.content: Initial investigations ​suggest that ⁠the fire which tore through a Swiss ski resort ​bar started ‍when 'fountain candles' attached ​to champagne bottles were carried ​aloft too close to the ceiling, the local prosecutor said on Friday. Authorities planned to look into whether the material on the ceiling that was designed to muffle sound conformed with regulations. FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot is on the ground.

items.title: Teenagers missing after deadly Swiss ski resort fire named
items.standfirst: More details of the deadly fire at a ski resort bar in Switzerland on New Year's Eve are emerging, with three missing teenagers named.
items.content: More details of the deadly fire at a ski resort bar in Switzerland on New Year's Eve are emerging, with three missing teenagers named.

items.title: 'A lot of questions asked' about Crans-Montana bar's security after deadly fire
items.standfirst: Swiss investigators are probing what caused a fire in a bar at an Alpine ski resort that left around 40 people dead and another 115 injured during a New Year's celebration. The severity of the burns has made it very difficult to identify bodies, and Swiss authorities say it could take weeks before all victims have been identified. FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot spoke to several witnesses of the fire in Crans-Montana.
items.content: Swiss investigators are probing what caused a fire in a bar at an Alpine ski resort that left around 40 people dead and another 115 injured during a New Year's celebration. The severity of the burns has made it very difficult to identify bodies, and Swiss authorities say it could take weeks before all victims have been identified. FRANCE 24's Olivia Bizot spoke to several witnesses of the fire in Crans-Montana.

items.title: 'It was like seeing people run out of hell' when Crans-Montana fire broke out
items.standfirst: As investigations into how the deadly blaze could have started in a Crans-Montana bar on New Year's Eve, testimonies are emerging about what they saw that night. At least 40 were killed and 115 others were injured, while many others are missing. Police are struggling to identify the victims due to the severity of the burns. FRANCE 2'4's Olivia Bizot spoke to an Italian tourist who saw the fire that night.
items.content: As investigations into how the deadly blaze could have started in a Crans-Montana bar on New Year's Eve, testimonies are emerging about what they saw that night. At least 40 were killed and 115 others were injured, while many others are missing. Police are struggling to identify the victims due to the severity of the burns. FRANCE 2'4's Olivia Bizot spoke to an Italian tourist who saw the fire that night.

items.title: At least 40 killed and 119 injured in Crans-Montana fire caused by 'sparklers', Swiss officials say
items.standfirst: Swiss officials told a press conference on Friday that the deadly fire at a Crans-Montana ski resort bar on New Year’s Eve, which killed at least 40 people, was likely caused by sparkling flares atop Champagne bottles that came too close to the ceiling. Authorities said 113 of the 119 injured have been identified, including 14 French and 11 Italians.
items.content: Swiss officials told a press conference on Friday that the deadly fire at a Crans-Montana ski resort bar on New Year’s Eve, which killed at least 40 people, was likely caused by sparkling flares atop Champagne bottles that came too close to the ceiling. Authorities said 113 of the 119 injured have been identified, including 14 French and 11 Italians.

items.title: A fire in a Swiss ski resort bar kills 40 people: What we know so far
items.standfirst: Swiss investigators are probing what caused a fire in a bar at an Alpine ski resort that left around 40 people dead and another 115 injured during a New Year's celebration. Most injuries, many of them serious, occurred when the blaze swept through the crowded bar less than two hours after midnight in southwestern Switzerland.
items.content: Swiss investigators are probing what caused a fire in a bar at an Alpine ski resort that left around 40 people dead and another 115 injured during a New Year's celebration. Most injuries, many of them serious, occurred when the blaze swept through the crowded bar less than two hours after midnight in southwestern Switzerland.

items.title: Sparklers atop bottles appeared to start Swiss bar fire, officials say
items.standfirst: Details are beginning to emerge about the fire that eruopted at the Constellation Bar in the Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana on New Year's Day.
items.content: Details are beginning to emerge about the fire that eruopted at the Constellation Bar in the Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana on New Year's Day.

items.title: Crans-Montana fire: what we know so far about how it could have started
items.standfirst: Switzerland is reeling from the deadly fire in ski resort Crans-Montana. Some 47 people were killed on New Years eve, more than one hundred people were severely burned. The first emergency is to treat the wounded and identify victims. Authorities are also investigating what caused the fire and whether the bar violated security norms.
items.content: Switzerland is reeling from the deadly fire in ski resort Crans-Montana. Some 47 people were killed on New Years eve, more than one hundred people were severely burned. The first emergency is to treat the wounded and identify victims. Authorities are also investigating what caused the fire and whether the bar violated security norms.

items.title: Swiss officials face painful task of identifying victims of deadly bar fire
items.standfirst: Investigators warn that with some of the bodies badly burned, the identification process could take weeks.
items.content: Investigators warn that with some of the bodies badly burned, the identification process could take weeks.

items.title: Partygoer seen trying to tackle flames in 'horror movie' ski resort fire that killed dozens
items.standfirst: About 40 people were killed and 115 injured in a blaze in at a New Year's Eve Party at an upmarket Swiss ski resort, with the disaster likened to scenes from a horror film.
items.content: About 40 people were killed and 115 injured in a blaze in at a New Year's Eve Party at an upmarket Swiss ski resort, with the disaster likened to scenes from a horror film.

items.title: About 40 people killed in Swiss Alps resort fire
items.standfirst: About 40 people were killed and more than 100 injured after a fire broke out at a bar at a popular Swiss Alps ski resort town on New Year's Eve, according to police. The president of the Swiss Confederation, Guy Parmelin, said that many of the victims were young people and include Swiss residents as well as tourists from neighboring countries and elsewhere.
items.content: About 40 people were killed and more than 100 injured after a fire broke out at a bar at a popular Swiss Alps ski resort town on New Year's Eve, according to police. The president of the Swiss Confederation, Guy Parmelin, said that many of the victims were young people and include Swiss residents as well as tourists from neighboring countries and elsewhere.

items.title: Dozens presumed dead after fire rips through Swiss ski resort bar
items.standfirst: Dozens of people are feared dead after a fire swept through a ski resort bar during a New Year’s celebration in Crans-Montana, Switzerland. NBC News’ Daniele Hamamdjian has the details.
items.content: Dozens of people are feared dead after a fire swept through a ski resort bar during a New Year’s celebration in Crans-Montana, Switzerland. NBC News’ Daniele Hamamdjian has the details.

items.title: Everything we know about deadly Swiss ski resort fire
items.standfirst: A fierce blaze that broke out in a Swiss ski resort during New Year's Eve celebrations killed at least 40 people and injured 119, officials said in their latest update on Friday afternoon.
items.content: A fierce blaze that broke out in a Swiss ski resort during New Year's Eve celebrations killed at least 40 people and injured 119, officials said in their latest update on Friday afternoon.

items.title: Around 40 dead and 115 injured after fire sweeps through Swiss ski resort bar

items.content: Around 40 people are dead and around 115 others were severely injured after a fire broke out during a New Year’s Eve celebration at a bar in a Swiss Alps resort, authorities said Thursday

items.title: Iranian protests amplify as they enter their sixth day
items.standfirst: Current protests in Iran, now in their sixth day, have become the biggest since 2022, when the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini in police custody triggered nationwide demonstrations. Although protests took root in economic issues, demonstrator chants against Iran's theocracy have been heard. US President Donald Trump threatened the US could intervene were protestors killed, prompting government representatives to denounce a 'red line'.
items.content: Current protests in Iran, now in their sixth day, have become the biggest since 2022, when the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini in police custody triggered nationwide demonstrations. Although protests took root in economic issues, demonstrator chants against Iran's theocracy have been heard. US President Donald Trump threatened the US could intervene were protestors killed, prompting government representatives to denounce a 'red line'.

items.title: Iran officials warn Trump of red line after his threat to ‘rescue’ protesters
items.standfirst: Foreign minister says Iranian military is on standby after US president said he would act if demonstrators were killedDonald Trump has threatened to intervene in Iran if its government kills demonstrators, prompting warnings from senior Iranian officials that any American interference would cross a “red line”.In a social media post on Friday, Trump said that if Iran were to shoot and kill protesters, the US would “come to their rescue”. He added: “We are locked and loaded, and ready to go,” without explaining what that might mean in practice. Continue reading...
items.content: Foreign minister says Iranian military is on standby after US president said he would act if demonstrators were killedDonald Trump has threatened to intervene in Iran if its government kills demonstrators, prompting warnings from senior Iranian officials that any American interference would cross a “red line”.In a social media post on Friday, Trump said that if Iran were to shoot and kill protesters, the US would “come to their rescue”. He added: “We are locked and loaded, and ready to go,” without explaining what that might mean in practice. Continue reading...

items.title: Anthony Joshua Crash Update: Driver Charged After Two Killed in Nigeria
items.standfirst: Adeniyi Mobolaji Kayode faces multiple counts after the vehicle hit a stationary truck on the Lagos‑Ibadan Expressway.
items.content: Adeniyi Mobolaji Kayode faces multiple counts after the vehicle hit a stationary truck on the Lagos‑Ibadan Expressway.

items.title: Anthony Joshua’s driver charged with dangerous driving after fatal crash in Nigeria
items.standfirst: British boxer was injured in collision that killed his personal trainer Latif Ayodele and strength coach Sina GhamiNigerian police have charged Anthony Joshua’s driver with causing death by dangerous driving after a fatal crash that killed two people.Adeniyi Mobolaji Kayode, 46, was also charged with driving without a valid driving licence and “driving without due care and attention, causing bodily harm and damage to property”. He is due to appear in court on 20 January. Continue reading...
items.content: British boxer was injured in collision that killed his personal trainer Latif Ayodele and strength coach Sina GhamiNigerian police have charged Anthony Joshua’s driver with causing death by dangerous driving after a fatal crash that killed two people.Adeniyi Mobolaji Kayode, 46, was also charged with driving without a valid driving licence and “driving without due care and attention, causing bodily harm and damage to property”. He is due to appear in court on 20 January. Continue reading...

items.title: Anthony Joshua discharged from hospital as driver in fatal car crash arrested
items.standfirst: The driver of the car involved in the fatal crash in which two friends of British boxer Anthoy Joshua were killed has been held by police in Lagos. Joshua had a lucky escape from the accident on the busy highway between Lagos and Ibadan on December 29 and was discharged from hospital on January 1. FRANCE 24's Sam Olukoya has more, from Abuja in Nigeria.
items.content: The driver of the car involved in the fatal crash in which two friends of British boxer Anthoy Joshua were killed has been held by police in Lagos. Joshua had a lucky escape from the accident on the busy highway between Lagos and Ibadan on December 29 and was discharged from hospital on January 1. FRANCE 24's Sam Olukoya has more, from Abuja in Nigeria.

items.title: Elon Musk’s Grok AI generates images of ‘minors in minimal clothing’
items.standfirst: Lapses in safeguards led to wave of sexualized images this week as xAI says it is working to improve systemsElon Musk’s chatbot Grok posted on Friday that lapses in safeguards had led it to generate “images depicting minors in minimal clothing” on social media platform X. The chatbot, a product of Musk’s company xAI, has been generating a wave of sexualized images throughout the week in response to user prompts.Screenshots shared by users on X showed Grok’s public media tab filled with such images. xAI said it was working to improve its systems to prevent future incidents. Continue reading...

The chatbot, a product of Musk’s company xAI, has been generating a wave of sexualized images throughout the week in response to user prompts.Screenshots shared by users on X showed Grok’s public media tab filled with such images. xAI said it was working to improve its systems to prevent future incidents. items.title: Ukraine's Zelensky names spy chief Kyrylo Budanov as new top aide
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Friday appointed military intelligence chief Kyrylo Budanov as head of his office, following the resignation of top aide Andriy Yermak over a corruption scandal. Budanov, credited with daring operations against Russia, will focus on security, defence and diplomatic efforts amid the ongoing war.

Budanov, credited with daring operations against Russia, will focus on security, defence and diplomatic efforts amid the ongoing war.

items.title: Israel accuses Mamdani of antisemitism on first day as New York mayor
items.standfirst: Foreign ministry says mayor has poured ‘antisemitic gasoline on an open fire’ by scrapping IHRA definitionIsrael’s foreign ministry has accused the New York mayor, Zohran Mamdani, of pouring “antisemitic gasoline on an open fire” after he reversed a recent order by the outgoing mayor, Eric Adams.“On his very first day as @NYCMayor, Mamdani shows his true face: he scraps the IHRA definition of antisemitism and lifts restrictions on boycotting Israel. This isn’t leadership. It’s antisemitic gasoline on an open fire,” the foreign ministry said in a post on X. Continue reading...
items.content: Foreign ministry says mayor has poured ‘antisemitic gasoline on an open fire’ by scrapping IHRA definitionIsrael’s foreign ministry has accused the New York mayor, Zohran Mamdani, of pouring “antisemitic gasoline on an open fire” after he reversed a recent order by the outgoing mayor, Eric Adams.“On his very first day as @NYCMayor, Mamdani shows his true face: he scraps the IHRA definition of antisemitism and lifts restrictions on boycotting Israel. This isn’t leadership. It’s antisemitic gasoline on an open fire,” the foreign ministry said in a post on X. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump threatens Iran over protest crackdown as deadly unrest flares
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump and top Iranian officials exchanged dueling threats Friday as widening protests swept across parts of the Islamic Republic, further escalating tensions between the countries after America bombed Iranian nuclear sites in June.
items.content: US President Donald Trump and top Iranian officials exchanged dueling threats Friday as widening protests swept across parts of the Islamic Republic, further escalating tensions between the countries after America bombed Iranian nuclear sites in June.

items.title: Tension escalates between Iran and the United States as Trump threatens intervention
items.standfirst: U.S. President Donald Trump and top Iranian officials exchanged dueling threats on January 2 as widening economic protests swept across parts of the Islamic Republic, further escalating tensions between the countries after America bombed Iranian nuclear sites in June. At least seven people have been killed so far in violence surrounding the demonstrations, which have increasingly seen crowds chanting anti-government slogans. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert tells us more about the situation.
items.content: U.S. President Donald Trump and top Iranian officials exchanged dueling threats on January 2 as widening economic protests swept across parts of the Islamic Republic, further escalating tensions between the countries after America bombed Iranian nuclear sites in June. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert tells us more about the situation.

items.title: US stocks rose again in 2025 after overcoming turbulence from tariffs and Trump’s fight with the Fed
items.standfirst: NEW YORK — It was a scary good year for investors. It was scary because the U.S. stock market plunged to several historic drops on worries about everything from President Donald Trump’s tariffs to interest rates to a possible bubble in artificial-intelligence technology. In the end, though, it was…
items.content: NEW YORK — It was a scary good year for investors. It was scary because the U.S. stock market plunged to several historic drops on worries about everything from President Donald Trump’s tariffs to interest rates to a possible bubble in artificial-intelligence technology. In the end, though, it was…

items.title: Wall Street ends 2025 near record highs after year of economic upheaval
items.standfirst: US markets buoyed by sustained rise in tech stocks as investors largely shrug off concerns over Trump tariffsWall Street finished 2025 near record highs on Wednesday, as ballooning tech valuations and hopes of lower interest rates helped stock markets defy a year of economic uncertainty.The benchmark S&P 500 rose 16.4% over the course of the year, closing at 6,845.50 on New Year’s Eve in New York, as investors largely shrugged off geopolitical uncertainty and the frenzy around artificial intelligence continued. Continue reading...
items.content: US markets buoyed by sustained rise in tech stocks as investors largely shrug off concerns over Trump tariffsWall Street finished 2025 near record highs on Wednesday, as ballooning tech valuations and hopes of lower interest rates helped stock markets defy a year of economic uncertainty.The benchmark S&P 500 rose 16.4% over the course of the year, closing at 6,845.50 on New Year’s Eve in New York, as investors largely shrugged off geopolitical uncertainty and the frenzy around artificial intelligence continued. Continue reading...

clusters.title: FBI says it thwarted planned New Year’s Eve terrorist attack in North Carolina
clusters.neutral_headline: FBI says it thwarted planned New Year’s Eve terrorist attack in North Carolina

items.title: FBI says it thwarted planned New Year’s Eve terrorist attack in North Carolina
items.standfirst: FBI says teen was planning Islamic State-inspired hammer and knife attack on Jews, Christians and LGBTQ+ peopleThe FBI has said it thwarted an alleged plot to carry out a New Year’s Eve terrorist attack on a grocery store and restaurant in North Carolina in support of the Islamic State (IS).Christian Sturdivant, 18, of Mint Hill – a town outside Charlotte – was arrested on 31 December as he was being released from a special medical facility. He was charged with attempting to provide material support to a foreign terrorist organization, the US attorney for the western district of North Carolina, Russ Ferguson, said at a press conference on Friday morning. Continue reading...
items.content: FBI says teen was planning Islamic State-inspired hammer and knife attack on Jews, Christians and LGBTQ+ peopleThe FBI has said it thwarted an alleged plot to carry out a New Year’s Eve terrorist attack on a grocery store and restaurant in North Carolina in support of the Islamic State (IS).Christian Sturdivant, 18, of Mint Hill – a town outside Charlotte – was arrested on 31 December as he was being released from a special medical facility. He was charged with attempting to provide material support to a foreign terrorist organization, the US attorney for the western district of North Carolina, Russ Ferguson, said at a press conference on Friday morning. Continue reading...

items.content: The FBI says it has disrupted a plot to attack a North Carolina grocery store on New Year's Eve, arresting a man who officials said was inspired by the Islamic State group and pledged his loyalty to the extremist militants.
